body:
Hum!!

I don't think Azure is the correct module to load in PowerShell Core (WSL/Linux).  You should use AzureRM.Netcore which is the one supported cross platform.

Azure module is only for Windows PowerShell.

:)
I used Azure as an example; it’s also failing for the module I really want, InvokeBuild. (That said, Azure is a Script module, why wouldn’t it work?)

First, I suggest to use AzureRM.Netcore.   As using Azure module won't installed in WSL because is a Windows module.

Currently, your scenario can't be reproduce.

![wslazureerr_2018-07-11_8-47-54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/42572317-5f57fe3a-84e7-11e8-900a-5e2f477845ae.jpg)

![wslazureerr2_2018-07-11_8-47-54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/42572891-9d3988b2-84e8-11e8-8721-7d9b02a0a9dc.jpg)

![wslazureerr3_2018-07-11_8-47-54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/42572997-ee78ec54-84e8-11e8-9292-1bab5021e0e3.jpg)

Ok, as I said before, I used Azure as an example; my apologies for the red herring here @MaximoTrinidad.

InvokeBuild is the module I'm actually trying to install. On my machine, the module downloads, but does not appear to install correctly: 

```powershell
> Install-Module -Force InvokeBuild -Verbose -Scope CurrentUser
VERBOSE: Using the provider 'PowerShellGet' for searching packages.
VERBOSE: The -Repository parameter was not specified.  PowerShellGet will use all of the registered repositories.
VERBOSE: Getting the provider object for the PackageManagement Provider 'NuGet'.
VERBOSE: The specified Location is 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/' and PackageManagementProvider is 'NuGet'.
VERBOSE: Searching repository 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/FindPackagesById()?id='InvokeBuild'' for ''.
VERBOSE: Total package yield:'1' for the specified package 'InvokeBuild'.
VERBOSE: Performing the operation "Install-Module" on target "Version '5.4.1' of module 'InvokeBuild'".
VERBOSE: The installation scope is specified to be 'CurrentUser'.
VERBOSE: The specified module will be installed in '/home/alastair/.local/share/powershell/Modules'.
VERBOSE: The specified Location is 'NuGet' and PackageManagementProvider is 'NuGet'.
VERBOSE: Downloading module 'InvokeBuild' with version '5.4.1' from the repository 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/'.
VERBOSE: Searching repository 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/FindPackagesById()?id='InvokeBuild'' for ''.
VERBOSE: InstallPackage' - name='InvokeBuild', version='5.4.1',destination='/tmp/1697404623'
VERBOSE: DownloadPackage' - name='InvokeBuild', version='5.4.1',destination='/tmp/1697404623/InvokeBuild.5.4.1/InvokeBuild.5.4.1.nupkg', uri='https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/InvokeBuild/5.4.1'
VERBOSE: Downloading 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/InvokeBuild/5.4.1'.
VERBOSE: Completed downloading 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/InvokeBuild/5.4.1'.
VERBOSE: Completed downloading 'InvokeBuild'.
VERBOSE: InstallPackageLocal' - name='InvokeBuild', version='5.4.1',destination='/tmp/1697404623'
```

I see your `$PSVersionTable.OS` is newer than mine. I'll try updating WSL and see if that makes a difference.

No change in behaviour after an upgrade of WSL, but I'm still on an older build than yours @MaximoTrinidad:

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0-preview.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.1.0-preview.3
OS                             Linux 4.4.0-17134-Microsoft #137-Microsoft Thu Jun 14 18:46:00 PST 2018
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

Ah! That will do it, with all the different versions of Windows 10.
:(

Let me look at that module.

@alastairs 

Works on my system!

![invokebuild_01_2018-07-11_9-43-27](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/42576026-8efe640a-84ef-11e8-9573-5d7fe1e66d14.jpg)
![invokebuild_02_2018-07-11_9-43-27](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/42576039-9353d008-84ef-11e8-8d73-fdcb0ff85a29.jpg)

And, I also, have the non-Insider version:

![invokebuild_03_2018-07-11_9-43-27](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/42576536-9d7a8e40-84f0-11e8-8113-376042742671.jpg)

Ok, thanks for the update @MaximoTrinidad. I'm a bit at a loss of how to proceed from here; [adding `-Verbose`](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/7264#issuecomment-404165340) to the installation attempt clearly indicates that the installation is not completing or, at least, seemingly silently failing. What avenues can I explore to troubleshoot this further?

First! I have the tendency to first open PowerShell with 'sudo pwsh-preview' and then use the 'Install-Module ...".  Are you using "sudo ..."?

:)
Thanks @MaximoTrinidad 🙂 I've tried it with `sudo pwsh-preview` as well, same result...

I've collected even more detailed logs from a run of `Install-Module` on my machine, in a `sudo` session. Here's the output, starting from the last line of [the Verbose log](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/7264#issuecomment-404165340) output.

```powershell
VERBOSE: InstallPackageLocal' - name='InvokeBuild', version='5.4.1',destination='/tmp/801868413'
DEBUG: 00:00:22.3447290 /tmp/801868413/InvokeBuild.5.4.1/InvokeBuild.5.4.1.nupkg
DEBUG: 00:00:23.0231080 Returning the call 'NuGetClient'::'InstallPackageLocal'.
DEBUG: 00:00:23.5740780 Returning the call 'NuGetClient'::'InstallSinglePackage'.
DEBUG: 00:00:23.6204030 PowerShell Script 'PSModule' Function 'Install-Package' returns null.
DEBUG: 00:00:23.6224580 Done calling powershell «Install-Package» «PSModule»
```

@alastairs can confirm as well with not only Ubuntu, but Debian and OpenSUSE as well.

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0-preview.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.1.0-preview.3
OS                             Linux 4.4.0-17713-Microsoft #1000-Microsoft Fri Jul 06 15:51:00 PST 2018
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

Installing any module fails to properly install:
```powershell
VERBOSE: The installation scope is specified to be 'CurrentUser'.
VERBOSE: The specified module will be installed in '/home/me/.local/share/powershell/Modules'.
VERBOSE: The specified Location is 'NuGet' and PackageManagementProvider is 'NuGet'.
VERBOSE: Downloading module 'posh-git' with version '0.7.3' from the repository 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/'.
VERBOSE: Searching repository 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/FindPackagesById()?id='posh-git'' for ''.
VERBOSE: InstallPackage' - name='posh-git', version='0.7.3',destination='/tmp/873133532'
VERBOSE: DownloadPackage' - name='posh-git', version='0.7.3',destination='/tmp/873133532/posh-git.0.7.3/posh-git.0.7.3.nupkg', uri='https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/posh-git/0.7.3'
VERBOSE: Downloading 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/posh-git/0.7.3'.
VERBOSE: Completed downloading 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/posh-git/0.7.3'.
VERBOSE: Completed downloading 'posh-git'.
VERBOSE: InstallPackageLocal' - name='posh-git', version='0.7.3',destination='/tmp/873133532'
```

Awesome!  Nice to see someone reproduce the issue. 
I don't know why I can't.

The only thing I'm suspecting is the use of the '-Score CurrentUser' as it may of more use in Windows.
Can some please share the exact one-liner to install it?

:)

There's always the possibility that something did happened to the PowerShell Core installation.  
I have unregister/register back to PSGallery repository and got different failure messages.  But, I was able to recover and install any module.

Here's my installation Verbose:
```
PS /home/maxt> Install-Module -Name InvokeBuild -verbose -Scope CurrentUser -Force
VERBOSE: Using the provider 'PowerShellGet' for searching packages.
VERBOSE: The -Repository parameter was not specified.  PowerShellGet will use all of the registered repositories.
VERBOSE: Getting the provider object for the PackageManagement Provider 'NuGet'.
VERBOSE: The specified Location is 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/' and PackageManagementProvider is 'NuGet'.
VERBOSE: Searching repository 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/FindPackagesById()?id='InvokeBuild'' for ''.
VERBOSE: Total package yield:'1' for the specified package 'InvokeBuild'.
VERBOSE: Performing the operation "Install-Module" on target "Version '5.4.1' of module 'InvokeBuild'".
VERBOSE: The installation scope is specified to be 'CurrentUser'.
VERBOSE: The specified module will be installed in '/home/maxt/.local/share/powershell/Modules'.
VERBOSE: The specified Location is 'NuGet' and PackageManagementProvider is 'NuGet'.
VERBOSE: Downloading module 'InvokeBuild' with version '5.4.1' from the repository 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/'.
VERBOSE: Searching repository 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/FindPackagesById()?id='InvokeBuild'' for ''.
VERBOSE: InstallPackage' - name='InvokeBuild', version='5.4.1',destination='/tmp/655074114'
VERBOSE: DownloadPackage' - name='InvokeBuild', version='5.4.1',destination='/tmp/655074114/InvokeBuild/InvokeBuild.nupkg', uri='https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/InvokeBuild/5.4.1'
VERBOSE: Downloading 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/InvokeBuild/5.4.1'.
VERBOSE: Completed downloading 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/InvokeBuild/5.4.1'.
VERBOSE: Completed downloading 'InvokeBuild'.
VERBOSE: InstallPackageLocal' - name='InvokeBuild', version='5.4.1',destination='/tmp/655074114'
VERBOSE: Module 'InvokeBuild' was installed successfully to path '/home/maxt/.local/share/powershell/Modules/InvokeBuild/5.4.1'.
PS /home/maxt>
```
Have this ever work before Preview.3?
Have you tried to reinstall PowerShell Core?  

It has to be something with the installation. 
Can you list the registered psrepository?
```
get-psrepository
```

@MaximoTrinidad Here is the table:

```powershell
PS /home/me> Get-PsRepository

Name                      InstallationPolicy   SourceLocation
----                      ------------------   --------------
PSGallery                 Untrusted            https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/
```

@MaximoTrinidad It is the same for me (unsurprising, in retrospect, as the package is resolved and downloaded fine):

```powershell
PS > Get-PsRepository

Name                      InstallationPolicy   SourceLocation
----                      ------------------   --------------
PSGallery                 Untrusted            https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/
```

I was previously able to install InvokeBuild (and other modules) fine on PowerShell Core 6.0 on WSL with Ubuntu 16.04.

@alastairs 

Hum!!  Have you tried to cleanup prior PowerShell Core version folders?
Like, cleanup any residual for previous version and I do a clean installation of Preview.3.

Something is conflicting with the module(s).

:)
@maximotrinidad this was a clean install of PS Core 6.1.0 preview 3 on a clean install of Ubuntu 18.04 😀
@alastairs same here, complete fresh installs.

No words!!  I got it working although I figured out something slightly different:
http://www.maxtblog.com/2018/06/installing-powershell-core-6-preview-3-in-ubuntu-18-04/

Not sure if it helps!

![ubu1804installmod_2018-07-13_18-52-52](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/42717374-73c75ed6-86ce-11e8-9bda-a3832cf8191f.jpg)
@MaximoTrinidad it works fine on macOS and a full blown Pop_OS! VM I have running where PS installs fine and the modules do as well. WSL seems to be the issue here.
@alastairs this really needs to be raised in the PowerShellGet Repo as this isn't a PowerShell Issue as such but an issue with that module - https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShellGet
This issue was moved to PowerShell/PowerShellGet#302
